question: During Charles II's reign, in 1665, there was a major outbreak of plague in ______ where thousands of people died, especially in poorer areas
The Union Jack is comprised of four countries’ crosses. They are: England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
tip: One symbol of the union between England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland was a new version of the official flag, the Union Flag. This is often called the Union Jack. The flag combined crosses associated with England, Scotland and Ireland. It is still used today as the official flag of the UK.

question: More serious civil cases (for example, when a large amount of compensation is being claimed) are dealt with in the ______ in England, Wales and Northern Ireland
______ is a national park in North Wales
How is the Speaker of the House of Commons chosen?
tip: The Speaker is chosen by other members of Parliament (MPs) in a secret ballot. The Speaker's role is to chair debates in the House of Commons.

question: The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages was a time of almost constant war.
tip: The period after the Norman Conquest up until about 1485 is called the Middle Ages was a time of almost constant war.

question: You need to be a member of a political party to be able to stand for election as an MP
tip: Anyone aged 18 or over can stand for election as an MP but they are unlikely to win unless they have been nominated to represent one of the major political parties.

question: Who gets appointed by local authorities to be the ceremonial leader of the council?
tip: Many local authorities appoint a mayor, who is the ceremonial leader of the council. In some towns, a mayor is elected to be the effective leader of the administration.

question: Everyone has the legal right to choose their religion in the UK, or to choose not to practice a religion
options: No, in the most forms you have choose what is your religion

question: As a British citizen, you should:
options: Look after the area in which you live and the environment

question: Who in 2002 was voted the greatest Briton of all time?
tip: In 2002, Winston Churchill was voted the greatest Briton of all time by the public.

question: ______ was the first to be extensively covered by media
Which TWO developments were features of the Industrial Revolution?
tip: Britain was the first country to industrialise on a large scale. This happened because of the development of machinery and the use of steam power.

question: Which of these is NOT part of the Commonwealth?
tip: The USA is not part of the Commonwealth.

question: The 1970s were also a time of serious unrest in Northern Ireland.
tip: The 1970s were also a time of serious unrest in Northern Ireland.

question: What day relates to the death of Jesus Christ?
The Union Flag consists of four crosses
tip:
The Union Flag consists of three crosses:
The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is a red cross on a white ground.
The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground.
The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white ground.

question: How many member states does the UN have?
tip: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members.

question: The UK has a declining elderly population.
tip: The UK has an ageing population. People in the UK are living longer than ever before.

question: A jury has 12 members in the UK
tip: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members, and in Scotland a jury has 15 members.

question: ______ can be traced back to 15th-century Scotland
Who was given the title of Lord Protector in the 17th century?
tip: Oliver Cromwell was appointed Lord Protector after the execution of King Charles I, when England was a republic without a king.

question: Who is credited with the introduction of the National Health Service (NHS) in 1948?
tip: In 1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS), which guaranteed a minimum standard of health care for all, free at the point of use

question: In Youth Courts, the name or photographs of the accused young person can be published in newspapers or used by the media
tip: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

question: When was England ruled by a republic and not by a monarch?
options: When Elizabeth I died without any successor
When the Carta Magna restricted the king's power
When kind Harold died after the Battle of Hastings

question: Which country(s) did Britain fight against during the Battle of Trafalgar?
tip: Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

question: Who wrote about their experiences in the First World War?
tip: Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon – were inspired to write about their experiences in the First World War.

question: You must treat everyone equally, regardless of sex, race, age, religion, disability, class or sexual orientation
tip: The statement is true.

question: Which two of the following are Civil War Battles?
Which of the statements is true?
options: Halloween is an American festival that has recently become popular in the UK
Halloween is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter.
tip: Halloween, 31 October, is an ancient festival and has roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter. Young people will often dress up in frightening costumes to play ‘trick or treat’. People give them treats to stop them playing tricks on them. A lot of people carve lanterns out of pumpkins and put a candle inside.

question: Which of the following is a bridge built by Isambard Kingdom Brunel?
Who is responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence?
tip: Secretaries of State are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

question: How many years did Charles I try to rule without Parliament?
tip: For 11 years, Charles I found ways in which to raise money without Parliament’s approval but eventually trouble in Scotland meant that he had to recall Parliament.

question: The European Union member states are
